description.p: The MCMC analysis object keeps a model and the associated moves and monitors. The object is used to run Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation on the model, using the provided moves, to obtain a sample of the posterior probability distribution. During the analysis, the monitors are responsible for sampling model parameters of interest.

constructor-help-entry.name: mcmc
constructor-help-entry.usage: mcmc( Model model, Monitor[] monitors, Move[] moves, String moveschedule = random )

argument.label: model
argument.description: The model to use in the analysis. The function makes an independent copy of the model and stores it internally in the MCMC object.

argument.label: monitors
argument.description: The monitors to use in the analysis. The function makes an independent copy of the monitors and stores them internally in the MCMC object.

argument.label: moves
argument.description: The moves to use in the analysis. The function makes an independent copy of the moves and stores them internally in the MCMC object.

argument.label: moveschedule
argument.description: The schedule used within this move, which is a mechanism on how to choose new moves. Either a new single move is chosen or a set of moves is chosen proportional to the sum of weights in sequential order or in random order.

details.p: The MCMC analysis object produced by a call to this function keeps copies of the model and the associated moves and monitors. The MCMC analysis object is used to run Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation on the model, using the provided moves, to obtain a sample of the posterior probability distribution. During the analysis, the monitors are responsible for sampling model parameters of interest.

constructor-help-entry.example:
# Create a simple model (unclamped) a ~ exponential(1) mymodel <- model(a)
# Create a move vector and a monitor vector moves[1] <- mScale(a, lambda=1.0, weight=1.0) monitors[1] <- modelmonitor("out.txt")
# Create an mcmc object mymcmcObject <- mcmc( mymodel, monitors, moves)
# Run a short analysis mymcmcObject.burnin( generations = 400, tuningInterval = 100) mymcmcObject.run( generations = 400)
# print the summary of the operators (now tuned) mymcmcObject.operatorSummary()

reference.citation: Metropolis N, AW Rosenbluth, MN Rosenbluth, AH Teller, E Teller (1953) Equation of state calculations by fast computing machines. Journal of Chemical Physics, 21:1087-1092.
Hastings WK (1970) Monte Carlo sampling methods using Markov chains and their applications. Biometrika, 57:97-109.

constructor-help-entry.author: Sebastian Hoehna

method-help-entry.name: burnin
method-help-entry.title: Burn-in an MCMC analysis.

description.p: Run a burnin simulation to let the MCMC procedure find the target distribution and to autotune move tuning parameters. No parameter values are sampled.

argument.label: generations
argument.description: The number of generations of the burnin run.

argument.label: tuningInterval
argument.description: The tuning interval in number of generations. The tuning interval should not be larger than the number of generations.

method-help-entry.example:
# Create a simple model (unclamped) a ~ exponential(1) mymodel <- model(a)
# Create a move vector and a monitor vector moves[1] <- mScale(a, lambda=1.0, weight=1.0) monitors[1] <- modelmonitor("out.txt")
# Create an mcmc object mymcmcObject <- mcmc( mymodel, monitors, moves)
# Run a short analysis mymcmcObject.burnin( generations = 400, tuningInterval = 100)
# print the summary of the operators (now tuned) mymcmcObject.operatorSummary()

method-help-entry.name: operatorSummary
method-help-entry.title: Show summary of the moves after an MCMC run.

description.p: This function provides information about the number of proposals, the acceptance rates and the tuning parameter after an MCMC sampler has run for some iterations.

method-help-entry.example:
# Create a simple model (unclamped) a ~ exponential(1) mymodel <- model(a)
# Create a move vector and a monitor vector moves[1] <- mScale(a, lambda=1.0, weight=1.0) monitors[1] <- modelmonitor("out.txt")

# Run a short analysis mymcmcObject.burnin( generations = 400, tuningInterval = 100)

method-help-entry.name: run
method-help-entry.title: Running an MCMC analysis.

description.p: Running an MCMC analysis for a given number of iterations. This may continue a previous run or start a new run if this is the first run. You can also run the MCMC under the prior which disregards the likelihood contribution from the clamped variables.

method-help-entry.usage: run( Natural generations, Bool underPrior = FALSE )

argument.label: generations
argument.description: The number of iterations the MCMC should run.

argument.label: underPrior
argument.description: If this MCMC should run under the prior by setting all the likelihoods from the clamped variables to 1.0.

details.p: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation is a numerical method that, in this program, is used to approximate the posterior probability distribution of the parameters of a model. The basic sampling mechanism we use is the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm (Metropolis et al. 1953; Hastings 1970).

An MCMC simulation is known to converge to the posterior probability distribution, such that the frequency with which a particular parameter value is sampled is a valid approximation of its posterior probability. However, convergence to the target distribution may be slow, so it is important to assess convergence to ensure that you are likely to have a reasonable sample from the posterior.

method-help-entry.example:
# Create a simple model (unclamped) a ~ exponential(1) mymodel <- model(a)
# Create a move vector and a monitor vector moves[1] <- mScale(a, lambda=1.0, weight=1.0) monitors[1] <- modelmonitor("out.txt")
# Create an mcmc object mymcmcObject <- mcmc( mymodel, monitors, moves)
# Run a short analysis mymcmcObject.run( generations = 100)

reference.citation: Metropolis N, AW Rosenbluth, MN Rosenbluth, AH Teller, E Teller (1953) Equation of state calculations by fast computing machines. Journal of Chemical Physics, 21:1087-1092.
Hastings WK (1970) Monte Carlo sampling methods using Markov chains and their applications. Biometrika, 57:97-109.
